column1: What is the most common endocarditis pathogen in IV drug users?
column2: Staph. Aureus (since it's found on the skin)

column1: How does Staph. Aureus endocarditis present?
column2: Acutely with more valvular/perivalvular destruction and high need for surgery

column1: Why does infective endocarditis require a long course of antibiotics?
column2: Antibiotics have poor penetration into vegetations (mix of organisms, platelets, fibrin-rich thrombus and inflammatory cells)

column1: What is a vascular complication of endocarditis vegetations?
column2: Infarcts or mycotic aneurysms. May need to do whole body angiogram.

column1: Whar are common signs and symptoms of infective endocarditis?
column2: Fever, murmur, chills

column1: What is the commonest cause of splinter haemorrhages?
column2: Trauma. If no traumatic history, may suggest infective endocarditis

column1: Name four types of non-infective endocarditis?
column2: Marantic - Associated with carcinoma (esp. bowel), Libman-Sacks (SLE), Loeffler's, DIC

column1: What is the highest risk for endocarditis in young people?
column2: IVDU

column1: What % of valve recipients develop endocarditis in the first year?
What is the treatment difference between normal valve endocarditis and prosthetic valve endocarditis?
column2: prosthetic valve disease responds less well to Abx

column1: What are the risk factors for endocarditis?
column2: IVDU, prosthetic mitral valve, nosocomial (cannulae/catheter bacteraemia), structural heart disease (bicuspid aortic valve), degenerative valvular lesions (mitral valve prolapse, aortic stenosis), Hx of endocarditis

column1: What is the most common cause of endocarditis globally?
column2: streptococci (viridans s.) (staph more common in 1st world, tertiary hospitals)

column1: What are the 2 forms of culture negative endocarditis?
column2: True culture negative (eg. Q fever); those inadvertantly treated with Abx early leading to control of organism, but not disease process)

column1: What peripheral embolic signs can be seen with IE?
column2: splinter haemorrhages, Janeway lesions, focal neuro signs, micro haematuria

column1: What peripheral immune complex signs can be seen with IE?
column2: Osler's nodes (painful, raised on digits), glomerulonephritis, arthritis, Roth's spots (eyes)

column1: What signs may be seen on CT with IE?
column2: Psoas abscess, multiple lung emboli

column1: What types of endocarditis are there other than infective endocarditis?
column2: non-infective endocarditis (trauma from procedures, SLE, carcinomatous endocarditis)

column1: What are risk factors for Q Fever?
column2: Working in or living near and abattoir  travel to Middle East

column1: What are the 2 applications of echocardiography in IE?
column2: To look for lesions; to look for complications (valvular dysfn, abscess/fistula, LV dysfn)

column1: Are mechanical or native replacement valves higher risk for IE?
column2: Same

column1: What is the commonest valve involved in IE?
column2: Mitral

column1: How many of Duke's criteria lead to a definitive diagnosis?
column2: 2 major or 1 major plus 3 minor or 5 minor

column1: What are the major Duke's criteria?
column2: Positive blood cultures for IE (multiple times  typical or consistent)  positive echocardiogram  new valvular regurgitation

column1: What are the minor Duke's criteria?
column2: Predisposing condition; fever; vascular phenomena; immunologic phnomena; positive blood culture not meeting major; echocardiograph findings consistent with IE, but not meeting major

column1: What are some limitations of echocardiography?
column2: Operator dependent; TTE is body shape dependent and low res; TOE is high res, but invasive

column1: What are the gram-negative bacilli associated with IE?
column2: HACEK: Haemophillus, Actinobacillus, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella

column1: What is the most common bacterial agent for IE in new mechanical heart valve recipients?
column2: Steptococcus epidermidis

column1: What is the incidence of IE?
column2: Not clear, but between 1.5-5 per 100,000 in the US. Men > Women

column1: When should TOE be used in IE diagnosis?
column2: When TTE result is unclear, or abscess/perforation suspected

column1: What are some of the local consequences of IE?
column2: myocardial abscesses, conduction disturbances, severe valvular regurg, aortitis

column1: What may be seen on a FBC for IE?
column2: anaemia, ESR, CRP

column1: What is the basic requirement for IE
column2: Damaged endothelium (valves, VSD, Chordae tendinae)

column1: What is the most likely organism for acute IE?
column2: Staph

column1: What % of sufferers of IE have a risk factor?
Is native valve or prosthetic valve more likely to be staph?
column2: Prosthetic (early especially)

column1: What % will present with a fever?
What % will have a murmur at presentation?
What would you use a Gallium scan for?
column2: Find where the focus of WBC (and hence infn) in the body (remove pt's blood, label WBCs, re-inject, wait, scan). Use in ambiguous cases where pt has implanted device and source of infn unknown.

column1: What is emprical Abx Rx for IE?
column2: Broad spectrum (Vanc + Gent + 3/4 Gen Cefalosporin)
